message: “use git instead” is a plenty good answer for my situation at least. thanks!
i figure i could load the .gitignore globs and use those as the `exclude` to rsync_project(), but i do have an untracked file kicking around
hmm, i was thinking i didn't necessarily want to push changes to github first, but i could push them directly to the server, couldn't i?
i was using rsync_project() to push code to a server, but decided i only wanted to upload the files that are under source control.
Does your server have git? Might want to switch to using git for pushing code, instead of the rsync style.
depending on the size of your project and the number of developers, having it pushed to GH first might be a good thing
you don't want to get in the situation where the server has commits that someone pushed directly, but nobody else has in their local repo
instead i copied upload_project() and replaced the `tar` with the analogous `git archive`.
does someone have a good recipe for doing an rsync of just the files in a git project?
i also ended up with tracked files that are under a .gitignored directory (for now), so excluding that whole directory would miss them

yeah, it's a tiny messy project right now so sometimes i've wanted to try changes on the server, but as i and the other developer collaborate more we might oughta switch the server to pulling from github
